FIFA World Cup.passage: The FIFA World Cup is an international football tournament contested by the men's national teams of members of Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the sport's global governing body. The championship has been held every four years since the first tournament in 1930, except for 1942 and 1946, due to World War II. The tournament consists of several stages, including qualifying rounds, and a final phase which is contested by 32 national teams. The host nation automatically qualifies, while the rest of the teams must go through a qualification process. The tournament is played in a knockout format, with each match decided by a single goal. Extra time and penalty shootouts are used to decide knockout matches if necessary. The tournament has been held in 24 different countries, with Brazil winning the most titles, five, and Italy and Germany winning four titles each. The most recent tournament was held in 2018, with the next one scheduled for 2022 in Qatar. The World Cup is the most-watched and most-followed sporting event in the world, with an estimated 3.5 billion viewers for the 2018 final. The tournament has also been marred by controversies, including match-fixing, doping, and corruption scandals. The World Cup has also been used as a platform for political and social issues, with boycotts and protests held by various countries and organizations over human rights abuses, political instability, and other concerns. In summary, the FIFA World Cup is a highly anticipated international football tournament that brings together the best national teams from around the world to compete for the title of world champions.

UEFA Champions League.passage: UEFA Champions League The UEFA Champions League is an annual continental club football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA). It was first held in the 1955–56 season and was initially called the European Champions' Cup. The competition was initially only open to the champions of the top-tier domestic league in each of the participating countries, but the format has been modified over the years. Today, the competition involves 79 teams from 54 countries, and is one of the most prestigious football tournaments in the world. Format The Champions League begins with a qualifying round in July and August, where the 10 winners from the third qualifying round enter the group stage. The 32 teams are then drawn into eight groups of four, with each team playing six matches against the other teams in their group. The top two teams from each group advance to the knockout stage, which begins in February of the following year. The knockout stage consists of two-legged ties, with the away goals rule used to determine the winner in the event of a draw. The quarter-finals, semi-finals, and final are all one-off matches, with extra time and penalty shootouts used to determine the winner if the score is level after 90 minutes. Prize money The Champions League operates on a system of prize money, with the winners receiving €1.9 billion (£1.6 billion) in 2021. This is distributed among the participating teams based on their performance in the competition, with the winners receiving the largest share. The prize money is funded by UEFA's commercial rights, including broadcasting deals and sponsorship agreements.

Wimbledon.passage: Wimbledon is a suburban area and town in southwest London, England, located in the London Borough of Merton, with a population of around 60,000 people. Super Bowl.passage: Super Bowl The Super Bowl is the championship game of the National Football League (NFL), which determines the league's champion for the season. The game is held annually in February and is one of the biggest sporting events in the United States. The Super Bowl is played on the first Sunday in February and is preceded by a week-long series of events and activities, including the Super Bowl Media Day, the Pro Bowl, and various parties and concerts. The first Super Bowl was held on January 15, 1967, at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, and was played between the Green Bay Packers and the Kansas City Chiefs. The Packers won the game by a score of 35–10, and have since gone on to win the most Super Bowls of any team with six victories. The Super Bowl has become one of the most-watched television events in the world, with an estimated 100 million viewers tuning in to watch the game in the United States alone. The Super Bowl is also known for its high-profile halftime show, which features some of the biggest names in music and is watched by millions of viewers around the world. The Super Bowl is played on a 120-yard field, with two 45-yard lines and two 20-yard lines. The game is divided into four quarters, each lasting 15 minutes, and if the game is tied at the end of regulation time, additional periods of 15 minutes are played until a winner is determined. The Super Bowl is considered the pinnacle of American football, and the winning team is widely regarded as the best team in the league for that year.

The Masters.passage: The Masters is a professional golf tournament that is held annually in April at the Augusta National Golf Club in Augusta, Georgia, United States. The Masters is one of the four major championships in professional golf, and it is the first major of the year. The tournament is held over four days and is played in a stroke play format. The field is limited to 97 players, including amateur and professional golfers. Jack Nicklaus holds the record for the most wins, with six, while Tiger Woods has won the tournament five times. Other notable winners include Arnold Palmer, Gary Player, and Tom Weiskopf. The course at Augusta National is known for its difficulty, with its narrow fairways, tricky greens, and water hazards. The course is also known for its speed, with the greens being some of the fastest on the PGA Tour. The Masters is also known for its television coverage, with CBS Sports providing live coverage of the tournament since 1956. US Open.passage: The United States Open Tennis Championships is a hard court tennis tournament that is the modern iteration of one of the oldest tennis championships in the world, the U.S. National Championship, which was first contested in 1881. The US Open is held annually in late August and early September, over a two-week period, and is the fourth and final Grand Slam tournament of the year, following the Australian Open, French Open, and Wimbledon. It is held at the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows–Corona Park, in Queens, New York City. The tournament is known for its night sessions, which begin at 7 PM and continue until 11 PM, and its extensive use of technology, including instant replay and electronic line calling. The tournament features men's and women's singles, men's and women's doubles, and mixed doubles events. The tournament is played in a best-of-five sets format for all events except for the mixed doubles event, which is played in a best-of-three sets format. The US Open is the only Grand Slam tournament that allows tie-breaks in every set, including the final set, which is not the case in the other three Grand Slam tournaments. the Union of European Football Associati.passage: Union of European Football Associations The Union of European Football Associations, commonly referred to by its acronym UEFA, is the administrative body for football in Europe. It was founded on 15 June 1954 in Solna, Sweden, and is headquartered in Nyon, Switzerland. UEFA's main responsibilities include organizing the UEFA European Football Championship and the UEFA Nations League, as well as managing the UEFA Champions League and UEFA Europa League. UEFA has 55 member associations, including countries from Europe and parts of Asia. The association operates under the leadership of a president, who is elected every four years. UEFA is responsible for setting the rules and regulations for football in Europe, as well as promoting the sport and developing grassroots initiatives. UEFA has a long history of promoting football in Europe, and has been instrumental in the growth of the sport on the continent. The organization has also been at the forefront of efforts to improve player safety and prevent match-fixing and other forms of corruption. UEFA has a number of partnerships with other organizations, including FIFA, the international governing body for football, and the European Broadcasting Union, which helps to distribute UEFA's media rights. The organization also works closely with its member associations to develop football at all levels, from grassroots to elite. Overall, UEFA plays a crucial role in the development and promotion of football in Europe, and is widely respected for its work in the sport.

The network is headquartered at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York City, with additional offices and studios at the NBC Universal Television Group in Burbank, California. NBC's programming includes a mix of comedy, drama, reality, and news shows, as well as sports events and movies. NBC was founded on November 15, 1926, as the National Broadcasting Company, when radio station WEAF in New York City and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation jointly purchased the rights to the American Broadcasting Company (ABC) from its founders, RCA. The network's first president was David Sarnoff, who later became a major investor in RCA. NBC was the first major broadcast network in the United States, and it dominated the radio industry through the 1930s and into the 1950s. NBC's dominance in radio began to erode in the 1940s with the rise of television, and the network struggled to compete in the new medium for several decades. However, in the 1980s, NBC began to regain its footing with hit shows like The Cosby Show, Miami Vice, and Cheers, and it became one of the top-rated networks in the United States by the 1990s. Wisconsin.passage: Wisconsin is a state in the north-central United States. It was admitted to the Union on May 29, 1848, as the 30th state. Wisconsin is bordered by Minnesota to the west, Iowa to the southwest, Illinois to the south, Michigan to the northeast, and Lake Michigan to the east. The state's capital is Madison, and its largest city is Milwaukee. Wisconsin is known for its dairy production, with milk being one of its largest agricultural products. The state is also famous for its cheese, which is made in many different varieties and styles. In addition to agriculture, Wisconsin has a diverse economy, with a mix of manufacturing, healthcare, and technology companies. Wisconsin is home to several prestigious universities, including the University of Wisconsin–Madison, which is one of the largest universities in the country. The state also has a strong tradition of public education, with a well-funded system of public schools and universities. Wisconsin is a popular tourist destination, with attractions such as the House on the Rock, the Wisconsin Dells, and the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore. The state is also home to several professional sports teams, including the Milwaukee Brewers (MLB), the Green Bay Packers (NFL), and the Milwaukee Bucks (NBA). In recent years, Wisconsin has become a battleground state in presidential elections, with close races in 2016 and 2020. The state has a reputation for being politically divided, with liberal strongholds in cities like Madison and Milwaukee, and more conservative areas in rural areas.

the United States.passage: United States The United States of America (commonly referred to as the United States or America) is a country of 50 states, a federal district, and various territories. It is located mostly in central North America, where its 3.9 million square miles (10 million km²) include both the world's third- and fifth-largest landmasses, North America and South America. The country's capital is Washington, D.C., and its largest city is New York City. Forty-eight of the fifty states and the capital district are contiguous in the upper part of North America between Canada and Mexico. The state of Alaska is in the northwest corner of North America, bordered by Canada to the east and across the Bering Strait from Russia to the west. The state of Hawaii is an archipelago in the mid-Pacific Ocean. The U.S. also has five major territories, including Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The United States is the world's third- or fourth-largest country by total area, and the third-most populous with a population of over 328 million people. It is one of the world's most ethnically diverse and multicultural nations, the product of large-scale immigration from many countries. The U.S. economy is the world's largest by nominal GDP, and the country has the world's largest defense spending. The United States is a developed country and has the world's largest economy by nominal GDP. The U.S. has the world's highest estimated number of incarcerated people, and is the only country in the world that has not signed the International Criminal Court agreement.
